overview_of_class: In this seminar we will examine some of the fundamental ideas and questions behind democracy and provide a reading of their "inventors". Some of the questions are: What is democracy? Is it a form of government, a value, an ideal, a political system, a form of life, a bit of all this? Is democracy always the best political solution (in wartime? general starvation?)? Why should the whole of the people decide and not the specialists in the respective questions? Are all democratically taken decisions automatically legitimate (what about minorities' rights?)? How should all citizens in a democracy participate in politics? By direct self-government of the people or by voting representatives? Is everything democratically decidable or does the individual have unalterable rights? Is tolerance and/or free speech necessary for democracy and how far can it go?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This Seminar will acquaint the students with the core ideas of major classics of democratic theory from Aristotle to Habermas. The method will be that of a historically guided systematic development of the normative ideal "democratic state", on which students at the conclusion of the course will be able to write a competent research paper that uses central sources. Writing with sources and producing a standard academic research paper will be the other main focus of the instruction in the Seminar.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: PARTICIPATION: ? 2 informal 10-minute presentations, ? 4 300-word reaction papers, ? steady and dedicated in-class discussion ? 1 draft of final paper & discussion thereof WRITTEN ASSIGNMENTS: ? 2 1000-word short papers ? 1 2500-word final research paper. PROPORTION (rule of thumb): Participation: ~33% (of which: reaction paper total ~15%, presentations ~25%, draft ~20%, class-discussion ~40%) + Short Papers (total) ~28% + Final Paper ~39%.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course Reader containing excerpts from (Books NOT REQUIRED) ? Aristotle: Politics, Oxford, New York: Oxford University Press, 1995. ? Locke, John: Second Treatise of Government, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1980. ? de Montesquieu, Charles-Louis: The Spirit of Law, Cambridge, New York: Cambridge University Press, 1989. ? Madison, James: The Federalist Papers, ed. by Isaac Kramnick, Harmondsworth: Penguin 1987. ? de Tocqueville, Alexis: Democracy In America, quoted from Cahn, Steven M. (ed.) Classics of Modern Political Theory, Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997, 722-752. ? Rousseau, Jean-Jacques: The Social Contract, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1987. ? Kant, Immanuel: Metaphysics of Morals, Cambridge, New York: Cambridge University Press, 1991, Perpetual Peace, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1982. ? Mill, John Stuart: On Liberty, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1978. ? Habermas, Juergen: "On the pragmatic, the ethical and the moral employments of practical reason," in Justification and application, Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 1993. ? The Declaration of Independence, The Constitution of the United States of America, quoted from The Federalist Papers, ed. by Isaac Kramnick, Harmondsworth: Penguin 1987.

overview_of_class: This course will address various conceptions of the aims and value of a college education. We will look at arguments from various quarters: humanist, economic, sociological/political, and skeptical. We will consider the question of the value of a college education not only from the perspective of the person in college, but also from the perspective of the broader community.

We will look at arguments from various quarters: humanist, economic, sociological/political, and skeptical. We will consider the question of the value of a college education not only from the perspective of the person in college, but also from the perspective of the broader community.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The purpose will be for each student to be able to recognize the strengths and weaknesses of various conceptions of the aims and value of a college education, to articulate her or his own views in relation to these, and to be able to defend those views against leading objections.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Five short (2-page) papers (10% each x 5 papers = 50% of total grade), one longer (5-page) term paper (40%), class participation (10%).

overview_of_class: Isaiah Berlin once declared that romanticism brought about "the greatest single shift in the consciousness of the West that has occurred." In this course, we will focus on romantic conceptions of poetry and language: particularly on the quintessentially romantic claim that art is capable of revealing truths that are inaccessible to us in any other manner. We will start with some precursors of the romantic movement in Germany (like Herder and Schiller), before proceeding to several representatives of the romantic movement in Germany and England (including the Schleiermacher, the Schlegels, and Shelley).
